description: From Middle English mastik, from Old French mastic, from Latin mastiche, from Ancient Greek μαστίχη (mastíkhē), from μαστιχάω (mastikháō, “I chew”) (note the chewing gum sense). Related to masticate.

entries.meaning: An evergreen shrub or small tree, Pistacia lentiscus (mastic tree), native to the Mediterranean.
examples: The island of Scio is now called by the Greeks Kio [Χιο], the antient Greek name of it was Chios [Χιος]; it was first called Ætalia in very antient times, and also Mastic, on account of the great number of mastic trees that were in this island.

entries.meaning: A hard, brittle, aromatic and transparent resin produced by this tree and used to make varnishes and chewing gum, and as a flavouring.
examples: The mastic, of which the people of Scio gather every year an incredible quantity, is a very rich gum, made use of in medicines, which distils from a shrub called, in Latin, Lentiscus.

entries.meaning: An alcoholic liquor flavoured with this resin.
examples: He took a list from the desk and read aloud Fatima’s offerings:—  […]  four bottles of rare mastic from Scio.

entries.meaning: A flexible, waterproof cement used as an adhesive, sealant or filler.
examples: ‘They have a few holes here and there. A few. Tiny tiny.’ ‘We could fix those up easy. Mastic cement. Not expensive, boss.’
